windows.explanation: Displays a list of files and subdirectories in the current directory. It is useful for quick navigation and viewing folder contents.
Change Directory. This command is used to switch the current working directory. You can use both absolute and relative paths.
Displays IP configuration details for all network adapters. This is essential for diagnosing network connection problems.
Shows a list of all running processes on a local or remote machine, including their Process ID (PID).
Clear Screen. This command erases all content in the command prompt window, leaving only a clean prompt.
Make Directory. Creates a new directory (folder) named 'NewFolder' in the current location.
Copies one or more files to another location. In this example, it creates a copy of file.txt with the name backup.txt.
Delete. Deletes one or more files. This command should be used with caution as deleted files are not sent to the Recycle Bin.
Displays detailed configuration information about the computer and its operating system.
Sends ICMP echo requests to a specified host to check for network connectivity and measure round-trip time.

linux.explanation: List. Lists files and directories in a long format (-l), including hidden files (-a). It shows permissions, owner, size, and modification date.
Print Working Directory. This command displays the full path of the current working directory.
Searches for lines containing the word 'error' within the file log.txt. It is a powerful utility for searching text.
Change Mode. Changes the access permissions of a file. In this case, '755' grants the owner full rights, while the group and others get read and execute rights.
Superuser Do. Executes a command with superuser (administrator) privileges. 'apt update' refreshes the available package list.
Creates a new, empty file with the specified name or updates the timestamp of an existing file without changing its content.
Remove. Recursively (-r) and forcefully (-f) deletes the 'old_stuff' directory and all its contents. This is a very dangerous command!
Disk Free. Shows information about disk space usage on all mounted filesystems in a human-readable format (-h).
Process Status. Displays detailed information about all currently running processes on the system.
Concatenate. Displays the content of the /etc/hosts file in the terminal. It is commonly used for viewing text files.

git.explanation: Clones (creates a local copy of) a remote repository located at the specified URL.
Displays the state of the working directory and the staging area. It shows which changes have been staged, which haven't, and which files aren't tracked.
Adds all current changes in the working directory to the staging area, preparing them for the next commit.
Records the staged changes into the repository's history. The -m flag allows you to provide a brief commit message.
Uploads committed changes from your local repository to its corresponding remote repository.
Fetches changes from a remote repository and automatically attempts to merge them into your current branch.
Creates a new branch named 'new-feature' but does not switch the working directory to it.
Switches the working directory to the specified branch (in this case, 'main').
Merges the commit history from 'feature-branch' into the current active branch.
Shows the commit history for the current branch. It is very useful for reviewing the history of changes.
